description.narrative:
Deforestation rate in protected forests in Kampong Speu, Kampong Chhnang, Battambang and Pursat provinces.
[Revised]

comment.narrative:
Trend in deforestation rates for 4 years before start of project in FA and MoE forests in target provinces.
[Revised]

Average deforestation rate in FA and MoE forests are 10% lower than rates in 4 years preceding project.
[Revised]

Zero Deforestation at target sites.
The current deforestation rate in the target sites is -0.46% per year; and the deforestation rate at the national level was 0.5% per year (baseline); indicating that there is no deforestation rate in the target sites. However, the deforestation rate in the target provinces is +0.71% per year, which indicates the increase of areas classified as non-forests. As the forest cover data of FA 2010 is not retrieved for the analysis of deforestation rate in the target sites, the national deforestation rate (FA 2010) is used as baseline: 0.5% per annum.
The remote sensing analysis, conducted by RECFOTC in Aug 2014, covered the North Cardamom Mountains Landscape (NCML) in the provinces of Battambang (BTB), Kampong Chnnang (KCH), Kampong Speu (KSP) and Pursat (PUR). The Forest Cover map 2006 produced by Forest Administration (FA) has been used as baseline data. The dataset was compared with the FA2006 map to determine the change happened in the interval. Due to the extent of the area only a comparison only between the total figures were carried out at provincial level. The results of this analysis included change analysis or trend in deforestation rates at both provincial level and the target site level.

description.narrative:
Land area covered by degraded forest as % of total forest cover in target sites in Kampong Speu, Kampong Chhang, Battambang and Pursat provinces.
[revised]

comment.narrative:
6.6%
[revised]

10% reduction in land covered by degraded forest relative to total forest cover by EoP.
[revised]

0.8% increase in land covered by degraded forest in the target areas.
Remote Sensing Analysis, RECOFTC, 2014:
-Land areas covered degraded forest at :
Target site = 7.4% Land areas covered by degraded forest in the target sites had increased from 6.6% (Baseline, FA 2006) to current status of 7.4%; meaning there has been an increase of 0.8% in degraded forest in the target sites of the project; while the project aims to reduce the areas covered by degraded forest of 10%. The project, with technical support from RECOFTC Chief Technical Advisor, conducted the remote sensing analysis to measure the deforestation rate and areas of degraded forests regarding the completion of project strategic result framework. Due to the limited scope of this assessment and the complex of technical issues, the study has defined the deforestation, within the context of the SFM project as the transformation from any forest types to non-forest areas, and the degradation forest has been identified as the transformation from Evergreen or Deciduous Forests to Other Forests.
Forestry Administration has yet identified the forest areas considering as degradation forests., due to the complex of technical issues and financial resources as required to measure the degraded forests. However, FA has assertively affirmed to conduct the assessment of degraded forests by 2016, as part of the REDD+ Strategy development.

description.narrative:
Annual greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reduction (ER) due to adoption of improved cook stoves at the national level.
[Revised]

comment.narrative: ER=0
ER= 61,000t CO2e/year

The 2014 Annual ER from ICS at the national level is 690,177 tCO2e/year (GERES ICS project in Cambodia)
At the national level, 590,753 units were sold in 2014. The total ICS sold as of Dec 2014 was 1,126,626 units.

description.narrative:
No. of a. CFs and b. CPAs around the Cardamoms that have completed all legalization requirements to operate as an indirect result of SFM efforts in building capacity and policy approaches in government.
[revised]

comment.narrative:
a. 72 CFs have agreement with FA
b. 20 CPAs have developed a number of steps under CPA guidelines
[revised]

a. 125 CFs (53 additional) have agreement with FA by EoP.
b. 34 CPAs approved by EoP.
[revised]

a. 88 CFs, including 21 target CFs, of all 155 CF in the target provinces have been approved by MAFF (CFO/FA Statistic 2015). The project is continuing to support 13 target sites (09 CFs and 04 ACFM) to get approval from MAFF.
b. 25 CPAs (including 11 target CPAs) of all 35 CPAs in the target provinces were recognized by MOE. All 11 target CPA sties have been working on CPA management plan process, which expected to be fully completed by end of the project.

description.narrative:
Indices of forest resources and condition in target community-managed forests
[New]

comment.narrative: Inventory of forest resources in CFs and CPAs, undertaken at the start of the CF process.
Indices remain at 100% of baseline levels by EoP.

The assessment of forest resource inventory has been undertaken, which agreed during the project midterm review, as means to understand the indices of forest resources and conditions in the community-managed forests. However, the project is going to conduct the second forest inventory exercises in the target CF/CPA in order to assess if there is any changes of forest resources.
Result of Forest Inventory in 30 target CFs:
-Evergreen Forest: 671 Ha divided to 9 CFMP blocks
-Semi-Evergreen Forest: 966 Ha divided to 5 CFMP blocks
-Deciduous Forest: 8106 Ha divided to 78 CFMP blocks
-Non forested areas & grasslands: 1136 ha divided to 21 CFMP blocks
Result of Forest Inventory in 11 target CPA:
-Evergreen Forest: 372 Ha divided to 4 CFMP blocks
-Semi-Evergreen Forest: 966 Ha divided to 5 CFMP blocks,
-Deciduous Forest: 8106 Ha divided to 78 CFMP blocks
-Non-forested areas & grasslands: 1136 ha divided to 21 CFMP blocks

31/42 (see project document annex 14)

description.narrative:
a. Recommendation for amendment of existing guidelines (if needed) in NFP for CF for additional modalities and business enterprise plan.
b. Recommendation for guideline documents for CPAs
[Revised]

comment.narrative:
a. Legal framework for CFs (2006) exists, but they are still lacking for ACFMs, and for business enterprise plan.
b. CPA guidelines are in draft form.
[Revised]

a. CF framework amended to include the additional modalities of CF, and business enterprise development.
b. CPA guidelines revised with lessons from SFM project.
[Revised]

The concept notes of ACFM (PF, CBPF, CCF) and Business Plan of CF drafted and presented to FA and relevant stakeholders. The field demonstration cover 04 sites (02 PF, 01 CBPF, 01 CCF). The documentation of lessons learned from the pilot sites have been documented by RECOFTC, including the specific recommendation to FA for amendment of existing CF guideline. b. MOE/DRCPAD had conducted series of sub-national consolation workshop to collect comment and feedback from relevant stakeholders on existing CPA guideline. Signification comment have raised included the revisions of roles and benefit of local community from the protect areas, to have self-sustain financing to continue protection and management of the CPA. The inputs and comment from workshops is going to presents and discuss in the national workshop, scheduling by end of the project.

description.narrative:
CLUP training module reflects SFM and energy by integrating CF and CPA development and sustainability.
[Revised]

comment.narrative:
Land use planning by local authorities includes some attention to SFM, but needs more focused approach.
[Revised]

Improved CLUP training module incorporating SFM and energy approaches established at Provincial and District levels.
[Revised]

The issue of SFM and fuelwood energy have been included in the facilitation process of CLUP development. The existing forests sites as well potential forest areas have been identified and included in the CLUP, as results, the target 5 CPA, 3CF, 1CCF, 2 PF integrated in CLUP process. The development of commune land used planning, which implemented in four target communes, had almost been completed. The provincial department of land management urban planning and construction is the leading government agency to develop the CLUP, which involved from various government institutions Department of Environment (DOE), Department of Agriculture (DpA), Forestry Administration Cantonment (FAC), Department of Mine and Energy, and commune council.

description.narrative:
Wood & Biomass Strategy drafted.
[Revised]

comment.narrative:
Wood & Biomass Energy Strategy updated database in formulation and approved for implementation.
[Revised]

Wood & Biomass Strategy developed to the point of approval.
[Revised]

Ministry of Industry, Mine and Energy (MIME) were divided into two (02) ministries: Ministry of Industry and Handicraft (MIH) and Ministry of Mine Energy. The change of government structures had also affected the project activity. Up to early 2015, Ministry of Mine and Energy, the responsible agency, had renewed the Wood Energy Working Group (WEWG) to continue finalizing the Wood and Biomass Energy Strategy Action Plan. As result, the survey on wood energy consumption had been conducted in 05 selected provinces to updated database in the strategy formulation. And the two-day national consultation workshop was conducted with relevant stakeholders. Up to now, MME/General Department of Energy (GDE) has been working internally to review the draft WBES based on comment from the consultation workshop.

description.narrative:
Annual volume of sustainable fuel wood produced from the wood lots starting Year X
[Indicator has been deleted as a result of MTR recommendation and consideration by project board and RTA]

comment.narrative: 0 baseline to be established
[Indicator deleted]

description.narrative: Financial strategies in MAFF and MOE to support SFM, including opportunities for REDD and carbon financing for sustained funding to support community-based forestry by Year 4

comment.narrative: X Qtr Year 4

The project has made effort to support the policies reform, including the exploring funding opportunities for community protected areas to be able to extract income from the implementation of eco-system services through partnering with other development partners. And the project has supported MME for the updated Wood and Biomass Energy Strategy, which the promotion of green charcoal under the SFM project, has been included as one of the priority actions plan in the WBES. As mentioned in the previous PIR Report, this activity is unlikely relevant to the project, but other UNDP supported project, UN-REDD and FCPF, have been working on this. Based on the updated progress of FCPF project, REDD+ strategy has been draft and revisions have been made following the series of technical consultation meetings with various stakeholders, including relevant government institutions and NGOs.
The project has called for proposals from NGO piloting the REDD+ related initiatives.

description.narrative: Financing generated from other funding sources (banks, green funds, etc.) by EOP

comment.narrative: Near zero

US$8,000 The project board recommended to use the data on Greenhouse gas emission reduction saved from ICS and charcoal under the SFM project. The SFM GHG ER monitoring report conducted by GERES showed that ER was of 30,894 tCO2 from the dissemination of 143,575 stoves and 17 operational ICK. Under the SFM project, about 58 tons of green charcoals had been produced from the operation of 17 efficient charcoal kilns, as of Dec 2014, which approximately earned about $8,000.

description.narrative: Community-based sustainable forest management is being implemented effectively within a context of cantonment, province, district and commune level planning delivering concrete benefits to local communities

No. of FA cantonment and DOE provincial PA offices that have community-based forest management development plans by EOP.
[Revised]

comment.narrative: 0 provinces
4 provinces

Besides the target CF, all 04 FAC had worked with other development partners to establish CF management plan. The CFO data in 2015 showed that there are 155 CF in the four target provinces, and 66 CF of them have been supported by FAC and various NGO to establish the CF management plan.
All 30 CFMP are being finalized based on the final comment from FA. 4 ACFM have progressed step 8 (CF inventory). The management blocks has been conducted in 3 sites. Out of the target 11 CPA in four provinces, DOE/PA in Battabang and Pursat have also supported other CPA for the management plan development (CPA data in 2014, DRCPAD). 11 CPAs had completed forest inventory. And result of forest inventory had already shared to local community. DOE/PA staff actively support CPAMC to prepare the CMPAMP and CMPBP. And the first draft CPAMP/CPMBP are ready by end of Q.3 2015.

description.narrative:
No. of CPAs with management plans and business plans that have passed final stage of approval process and are being implemented.
[Revised]

comment.narrative: 0 CPAs
10 CPAs have passed the final stage of approval proces by EoP

None of all 11 target CPAs have completed and approved the management and business plan. The current progress is likely to complete the CPA MP and BP by end of the project. 11 CPAs had completed forest inventory. And result of forest inventory had already shared to local community. DOE/PA staff actively support CPAMC to prepare the CMPAMP and CMPBP. And the first draft CPAMP/CPMBP are ready by end of Q.3 2015. As of June 2015, all 11 CPAs completely reached step 6 (natural resources assessment and forest inventory, study the customary use need of CPA, and drafting CPA management), which 5 of them completed this step.

description.narrative:
Baseline established allowing for regular monitoring for lessons learnt with respect to project results. Baseline to include gender segregated data on women\'s labor and income.

description.narrative:
Number of CFs with management and business plans that have passed final stage of approval process and are being implemented.
[Revised]

comment.narrative: 0 CFs

a. 34 CFAs (including 30 CFs and 4 ACFMs) have passed the final stage of approval process by EoP.
[Revised]

All 30 target CF have reached final stage of management plan approval process; and are being implemented. 4 ACFM have progressed step 8 (CF inventory). The CFMP of all 30 CF were draft and have been reviewed by FA technical team already. The detail plan of CFMP were carefully reviewed including the proposed annual activity plan, objective of management blocks, result of forest inventory, level of demand and supply of forest resources by local people. This review helped ensure the proper management of the forest resources. Up to now, 22 CFs have stated collecting forest resources, in particular non-forest timber products, in accordance the management plan and business plan. 22 FACs officer who attend TOT training participate SFM staff to facilitate CFMP & CFBP and ACFM implementation. 10 DOE &WS officer who attend TOT training have participated with SFM staffs to facilitate 11 CPAMP and 11 CF business plan.

description.narrative: No. of locally commune-based land use plan (CLUP) for SFM based on CF/CPA developed

comment.narrative: 4 CLUPs by EoP

Four (04) commune land use plans (CLUPs) for SFM developed. All four CLUP books completely developed, and two of them got approval from provincial governors, while the remaining two CLUP books have been submitted to the provincial state land use committee. The issue of SFM have been included in the CLUP development process. The existing forests sties as well potential forest areas have been identified and included in the CLUP, as results, the target 5 CPA, 3CF, 1CCF, 2 PF and 2 WISDOM integrated in CLUP process.

[Revised]

comment.narrative:
Income derived from SFM by target households before implementation of the business plan
[Revised]

Increase in average annual income by 20% from the baseline level by EoP.
[Revised]

As of June 2015, most CF has earned income generation from forest based business including fuel wood, Bamboo, mushrooms, wild vegetables, red ants and traditional medicine, which provided benefited to about 1,169 CF members.
The formal assessment of income from forest based business to be conducted at EoP.

20% in relation to baseline One-fifth of households with increased income are women-headed

The formal assessment of income from forest based business to be conducted at EoP.
The specific case studies conducted by RECOFTC on the implementation of forest-based business in some selected CF has positively shown the improvement livelihood of poor community members.

description.narrative: No. of operational improved cook stove production centres

comment.narrative: 25 cluster
8 additional at EOP

08 ICS clusters, consisting of 45 producers, fully established (06 clusters in KCH, one in KSP, and one in PST) and operated the ICS production (including NKS and NLS stove).
It is noticed that major ICS production are in Kampong Chhnang province, where producers, distributors, are at Kampong Chhnang.
The ICS production plan of each producer were developed and regularly monitored to ensure the production of ICS is achievable.
The ICS monitoring data in May 2015 reported that all ICS were sold, as the demand of ICS has been notably increased.

description.narrative:
Average income of stove producers
[Revised]

comment.narrative: $40/month
$60/month by EoP

$86.53/month (Average income of stove producer)
(Re: GERES stove producers profitability assessment, Dec 2014).
As of June 2015, All 45 ICS production unit owners have increasingly employed local people up to 180 employees. And based on the income analysis of ICS, conducted by GERES, the income margin is about 800 riels ($0.2) per stove, and in average, the ICS employee could produce at least 30 stoves per day.

People with disability have increased opportunities for participation in social, economic, cultural, and political life through effective implementation of the National Disability Strategic Plan(NDSP)

title.narrative: Disability Right Initiative Mid Term Review

description.narrative: Increase interaction and accountability of elected bodies and authorities to citizens through strengthened democratic processes at the national and sub-national levels.
Human rights affairs
Supporting Government implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities
Human rights affairs
Supporting Disabled Peoples Organisations to raise the voice and protect the rights of people with disability
Human rights affairs

1. No. of advocacy strategies developed, based on strong evidence and implemented to influence government ministry and institution to develop disability inclusive policies 2. No. of persons with diverse disabilities, including women have increased participation in democratic processes 3. No. of advocacy strategies developed & implemented to influence key ministries to improve the implementation of disability law and UNCRPD on access to information, public accessibility, and access to employment 4. Increased awareness about the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (UNCRPD) demonstrated by the general public 5. Increased awareness on disability rights & issues among targeted groups (general public, NGOs, government ministries, persons with disabilities, private sector, and Disabled People Organizations (DPOs)) 6. Increased awareness about UNCRPD among DPOs, key relevant ministries, disability NGOs and CSOs

comment.narrative: There is no data available for baseline.

1. 5 (1-One advocacy strategy developed for ministry of information to ensure disability is included into their policies and framework; 2-One advocacy strategy for National Election Committee developed; 3-Two disability advocacy statements developed and submitted to government for actions disability type and classification policy, pension scheme for persons with disabilities; 4-One advocacy strategy for National Committee for Disaster Management developed) 2. 2,000 (45% are women with disabilities) persons with diverse disabilities participated in the democratic process (commune investment process) & 60% of members (136,000) are able to join the community activity and have rights/voices to make decision. 3. 5 (1-One advocacy strategy on information policy developed; 2- One advocacy strategy on election policy developed; 3- One advocacy strategy on disaster risk management developed; 4- 3 statements on improving the national disability and UNCRPD implementation type and level of disability classification policy, pension scheme for persons with disabilities, job employment at private sector). 4. About 100,000 people will receive awareness on UNCRPD through IEC materials, radio programme and campaigns/forums. 5. 136, 000 received awareness on disability rights and those 40% are able to actively participate in awareness campaigns/forums. 6. 30% increase awareness about UNCRPD among DPOs, key relevant ministries, disability NGOs and CSOs.

1. 7 (One advocacy strategy for MoInf.; One advocacy strategy for NEC; Four advocacy statements submitted to gov't for pension & disability classification data and one advocacy strategy for National Committee for Disaster Management) 2. 1700 (45% are women with disabilities) persons with diverse disabilities participated in the democratic process (commune investment plan and 450 persons with disabilities received ID poor card) and about 80% of members with disabilities were able to involve in community activity and DPOs activity plan process. 3. 7 advocacy strategies (MoInf, NEC, Disaster Risk Management and four statements on improving the national disability and uncrpd implementation ) 4. 124,694 including 24,694 persons with disabilities received awareness on UNCRPD through video/radio talk show and disability awareness events. 5. 124,694 including 24,694 persons with disabilities received awareness on disability rights and 18% were able to actively participate in awareness campaigns/forums. 6. 20% of DPOs, key relevant ministries and disability NGOs and CSOs increased knowledge through the active involvement of the UNCRPD reporting process

1. Disability inclusive policy implemented by NEC to ensure persons with disabilities enable to vote. 2. Voting registration identified the types of persons with disabilities for those who have registered. 3. Women with disabilities at leadership level increased to match the 50/50 gender policy within DPOs 5. Shadow report of UNCRPD drafted 6. CDPO membership database disaggregated by type & location of entity
